docs.lead_paragraph: The city's jails have computerized the standard medical screening process for all newly arriving inmates, city health officials said yesterday, eliminating an antiquated paper-based system that often vexed jail health care workers. The move toward an automated checklist is one of several initiatives started in recent months by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene to better coordinate medical and mental health care for inmates.

headline.main: Medical Data At City Jails Enter the Era Of Computers

docs.abstract: New York City jails computerize all medical intake forms and screening data, which allows inmates with prior prison records to get care more efficiently; Health and Mental Hygiene Department Deputy Commissioner Louise Cohen says that jail inmates are more medically needy than general population and automated records will help provide better care on many levels (M)
docs.snippet: The city's jails have computerized the standard medical screening process for all newly arriving inmates, city health officials said yesterday, eliminating an antiquated paper-based system that often vexed jail health care workers.      The move...
docs.section_name: Technology; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Staking a position on a politically sensitive issue, Eliot Spitzer, who is running for governor, promised at a press conference on Wednesday that his administration would push for a $1 billion bond to pay for stem cell and other medical research. Mr. Spitzer, the state's attorney general, said the money for research on stem cells and other promising treatments would be the ''centerpiece'' of the state's health care policy if he were elected.

headline.main: Spitzer Unveils $1 Billion Stem Cell Proposal

docs.abstract: New York Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer promises to make $1-billion bond issue for medical research, including stem cell research, centerpiece of his health care policy if he is elected governor; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Staking a position on a politically sensitive issue, Eliot Spitzer, who is running for governor, promised at a press conference on Wednesday that his administration would push for a $1 billion bond to pay for stem cell and other medical research.    ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Salamanders can do it. Why not humans? Scientists try to harness the genes that let animals replace lost body parts.

docs.lead_paragraph: For any given symptom, like anxiety, there are a multitude of potentially responsible medical culprits.

headline.main: Anxiety About Anxiety Saved a Patient's Life
headline.print_headline: Anxiety About Anxiety Saved a Patient's Life

docs.lead_paragraph: SIXTEEN years ago, a small-scale study of human growth hormone therapy among older men opened a large debate in the medical community over whether it could stave off physical decline. Since then, the arguments on both sides have become only more passionate. Demands for prescriptions have increased, as has online demand for both legitimate and fraudulent forms of the product, known as HGH -- eventually growing into an estimated $1 billion global market.

headline.main: Growth Hormone: The Secret of Youth or a Cautionary Tale?

docs.abstract: Demand for human growth hormoneas anti-aging product stirs concern among some doctors because of potentially harmful side-effects; geriatrician Dr Robert N Butler warns of experimentation with unsuspecting people and says that nutrition and exercise will yield equal or better results in building muscle mass and increasing well-being; Dr Eric Braverman is among doctors defending use of HGH at low, carefully supervised levels (special section, Retirement)
docs.snippet: SIXTEEN years ago, a small-scale study of human growth hormone therapy among older men opened a large debate in the medical community over whether it could stave off physical decline.     Since then, the arguments on both sides have become only more...

docs.lead_paragraph: HANK McKINNELL, the chairman and chief executive of Pfizer, the $51 billion-a-year pharmaceutical company, and chairman of the Business Roundtable, an organization of chief executives, argues that C.E.O.'s are increasingly committed to socially responsible corporate behavior because it is essential to profitability. Here are excerpts from a conversation: Q. How does the social and political environment around you affect your ability to make money? A. If we're seen by the community as providing goods and services that enable people to live a happy, long life, society will want us to succeed. If they see what we're doing in education and sports programs, that's important. Otherwise, society will hope that we will fail.

headline.main: The Impact of Image On the Bottom Line

docs.abstract: Excerpts from interview with Pfizer chairman-chief executive Hank McKinnell, who is chairman of Business Roundtable, on chief executive officers who are increasingly committed to socially responsible corporate behavior because it is essential to profitability; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: The chief executive of Pfizer argues that C.E.O.'s are increasingly committed to socially responsible corporate behavior because it is essential to profitability.

docs.lead_paragraph: Like many surgeons, Dr. Yves Laurissaint is a man supremely sure of himself. ''I've trained a lot of other surgeons to do this operation,'' he said as he sliced open the engorged scrotum of 68-year-old Gesner Nicé, emptied more than a pint of clear liquid, then began trimming away with a cauterizing scalpel, filling the operating room with the acrid smell of burning skin. ''But they don't do it. They say it's too complicated.''

headline.main: Beyond Swollen Limbs, a Disease's Hidden Agony

docs.abstract: Fourth article in series about diseases that are extinct in developed world but persist in many poorer countries; lymphatic filariasis is endemic in poor tropical countries, afflicting both men and women with swollen legs of elephantiasis; worm-caused disease is still uncurable but world health experts hope to eliminate it within generation because its spread can be prevented with deworming drugs that can even be distributed in salt; photos; map; diagram (L)
docs.snippet: Health experts hope to eliminate lymphatic filariasis, which causes lymph nodes to swell, within a generation.

multimedia.caption: Slide Show: Victims of Filariasis
multimedia.credit: Lymphatic filariasis, which causes lymph nodes to swell painfully, is not curable, but health experts hope to eliminate the disease within a generation.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Charles L. Schepens, an eye researcher who developed sight-saving procedures and invented a device for viewing the retina that has, in turn, brought about new treatments to prevent blindness, died on March 28 at a hospital in Salem, Mass. He was 94. His death was announced by the Schepens Retina Associates Foundation, which he founded.

headline.main: Charles L. Schepens, Eye Researcher, Dies at 94

docs.abstract: Dr Charles L Schepens, eye researcher who developed binocular indirect ophthalmoscope, dies at age 94; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Charles L. Schepens developed sight-saving procedures and invented a device for viewing the retina that has, in turn, brought about new treatments to prevent blindness.

docs.lead_paragraph: The mission of the HealthWell Foundation sounds unassailable. Founded two years ago, HealthWell offers financial assistance to patients who need help paying for medical care to treat cancer, rheumatoid arthritis and other diseases. HealthWell is just one of several foundations that assist patients in making their insurance co-payments for expensive drugs. With the January rollout of Medicare Part D, which requires most patients to come up with $3,600 in co-payments annually before receiving full coverage, the foundations are busier than ever.

headline.main: In Drug-Aid Foundations, a Web of Corporate Interests

docs.abstract: Drug-aid foundations, which assist patients in making insurance co-payments for expensive drugs, say they are busier than ever since rollout of Medicare Part D; federal laws bar pharmaceutical companies from directly giving money to patients for co-payments on drugs they make but critics of co-pay foundations say they are skirting law by solicting funds from companies to be spent on very narrow categories of disease for which only one or two treatments exist; detractors also say ties between foundations and their corporate creators present obvious conflict of interest (M)
docs.snippet: The mission of the HealthWell Foundation sounds unassailable. Founded two years ago, HealthWell offers financial assistance to patients who need help paying for medical care to treat cancer, rheumatoid arthritis and other diseases.
